My Via Dinarica Adventure

Trail report about my Via Dinarica thru-hike in 2021

Follow my trail across the Balkans

My experience on the Via Dinarica white trail

This is my interpretation of the Via Dinarica white trail. I started in Razdrto, Slowenia at the beginning of August in the scorching sun. I reached Valbone Valley, Albania on the last day of October in 2021 on a freezing but sunny autumn day.

Feel free to download and use my Via Dinarica GPX tracks for your own orientation.

Disclaimer: Please be aware that I made some alterations to the official Via Dinarica trail. Some were voluntary forays due to my own curiosity or recommendations I got from fellow hikers or local guides. Many were involuntary detours due to, well, you know what it's like... impossible trails, overgrown paths, lack of markings or simply bad weather. I highly recommend comparing my tracks with other Via Dinarica resources and following your own common sense.

If you're up for an adventurous trail, you will love the Via Dinarica (and often curse it of course, and then love it even more once you're back on track)!

I plan to publish detailed trail reports continuously.

What is the Via Dinarica?

Some facts and insights for you

The Via Dinarica is a long distance hiking trail of roughly 1.300km in the Balkans. It starts in the woods of Slovenia, leads across Croatia's mountains and along its coastline, runs through vast plains and mountain ranges of Bosnia and Herzegovina, across vast mountain planes and steep valleys of Montenegro until reaching its end in northern Albania's peaks and valleys. When I first discovered it, I was both intrigued and intimidated.

To be honest, even after I decided to try it, I was unsure whether I would make it to the end. I had never done such a long hiking trail before, and - being a woman - had never dared to do a solo hiking trip, had never been to the Balkans and knew close to nothing about language, history or cultural context in this area.

The good news is - spoiler alert - I did it! ðŸ˜Š And it was not only possible but also a lot of fun!

Some more hard facts

You will notice that I didn't actually hike every meter of the Via Dinarica. I fortunately realized early on that it pays off to be kind to myself instead of stubbornly forcing things to go according to plan. They never do and actually, many plans B turned out surprisingly well! Plus, I made it a habit to learn from fellow hikers and avoid their mistakes or hardships. I therefore made up my own version of the trail where I didn't like the original route and occasionally bypassed or skipped episodes when it made sense to me or the weather got too bad to continue.

This is my trail summary in kilometers:

  • Total distance hiked: 1,130.8 km
  • Other transportation: 259.2 km
    • Hitchhiking: 138.9 km
    • Train: 66.4 km
    • Bus: 48.7 km
    • Taxi: 5.2 km
  • Total distance travelled: 1,390.8 km

This is how much time I spent on the trail:

  • Total hiking days: 58 days
  • Extra non-hiking days: 25 days
    • Rest days due to bad weather conditions: 13 days
    • Rest days for resting purposes: 7 days
    • Rest days due to illness: 3 days
    • Getting to and back from the trail: 2 days
  • Total days on tour: 83 days

I got stuck in quite a bad weather front in Montenegro and had to take a long break which I spent by lake Skader close to the coast. The climate is much milder by the seaside - and the trainride there is an adventure of itself! Fortunately, the first snow in the mountains was not the onset of winter yet. So after 10 long days of waiting, I was able to carry on and complete my journey all the way to Valbone, Albania.
